title: Non-Convulsive Status Epilepticus (NCSE)
scope: ** Diagnosis, acute management, and follow-up of non-convulsive status epilepticus in adults. Covers NCSE in patients with altered consciousness without overt convulsions, including NCSE after convulsive SE (subtle SE), de novo NCSE, NCSE in critically ill patients, absence SE, focal NCSE with impaired awareness, and electrographic seizures on continuous EEG monitoring. Includes EEG criteria, benzodiazepine trial protocol, and escalation to anesthetic infusions. For convulsive status epilepticus, see "Status Epilepticus" template. For new-onset seizures, see "New Onset Seizure" template. For refractory SE management details, see "Status Epilepticus" template (significant overlap -- use both templates for refractory cases).

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/epilepsy for NCSE confirmation, EEG interpretation, and treatment guidance
Neurointensive care/critical care for anesthetic infusion management and airway protection
EEG technologist for immediate cEEG hookup (availability critical for NCSE diagnosis)
Infectious disease if CNS infection suspected or confirmed
Neurosurgery if structural lesion amenable to surgical intervention identified
Pharmacy for ASM dosing optimization, drug interactions, and therapeutic drug monitoring
Epilepsy surgery team if refractory focal NCSE from identifiable lesion
Palliative care for goals of care discussion if super-refractory NCSE with poor prognosis
Social work for family support, education, and discharge planning

Patient/Family Instructions.item: NCSE is a serious neurological emergency where the brain is having continuous seizure activity without visible convulsions -- it requires urgent treatment
Recovery from NCSE depends on the underlying cause and duration of seizure activity -- discuss prognosis with neurology
Anti-seizure medications will likely be continued long-term; do NOT stop them without neurologist approval
Report any new confusion, behavior changes, or subtle symptoms (staring, fumbling, unresponsiveness) that may indicate recurrent seizures
Do NOT drive until seizure-free for state-mandated period AND cleared by neurology
Avoid alcohol, recreational drugs, sleep deprivation, and missed medications (all lower seizure threshold)
Return to ED immediately for any seizure, prolonged confusion, or unresponsiveness
Medication adherence is critical -- set reminders, use pill organizers, refill medications before running out
Family members should know seizure first aid and when to call 911

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Consistent sleep schedule (7-9 hours nightly) to reduce seizure risk
Avoid seizure triggers: sleep deprivation, excessive alcohol, flashing lights (if photosensitive), missed medications
Medication reconciliation to avoid drugs that lower seizure threshold (tramadol, bupropion, fluoroquinolones, meperidine)
Medical alert bracelet indicating seizure disorder and medications
Follow-up EEG as directed by neurology to monitor for subclinical seizure activity

differential.features: No electrographic seizure activity on EEG; diffuse slowing ± triphasic waves (not NCSE); metabolic derangement identified
differential.tests: EEG (no seizure activity); metabolic labs; triphasic waves resolve with metabolic correction

differential.features: Follows witnessed convulsive seizure; EEG shows slowing but NO ongoing seizure activity; gradual improvement
Focal deficits matching lesion; imaging abnormal; may cause NCSE (dual pathology)
differential.tests: MRI brain; CT head; EEG to differentiate lesion-related encephalopathy from NCSE

differential.features: Medication/substance exposure; EEG shows diffuse slowing not seizure pattern
differential.tests: Urine drug screen; medication levels; EEG

differential.features: Fever; meningismus; CSF abnormalities; may cause NCSE (dual pathology)
differential.tests: LP; CSF analysis; PCR panels; blood cultures

differential.features: Subacute onset; psychiatric symptoms; antibody-positive; may present AS NCSE
Normal EEG during episode; response to verbal cues or noxious stimuli; no post-event confusion
Psychiatric history; waxy flexibility; posturing; normal EEG; responds to lorazepam (clinical improvement with EEG unchanged)
differential.tests: EEG (normal); Bush-Francis scale; lorazepam challenge with clinical but not EEG response

differential.features: Rapidly progressive dementia; myoclonus; characteristic EEG (periodic sharp wave complexes, not true seizures)
differential.tests: MRI DWI cortical ribboning; 14-3-3; RT-QuIC; EEG (periodic discharges ≠ seizures)

differential.features: Preserved vertical eye movements and consciousness; basilar artery occlusion
No brainstem reflexes; no motor response; EEG shows electrocerebral silence
differential.tests: Brain death protocol; EEG (isoelectric); ancillary tests

monitoring.frequency: Continuous (minimum 24-48h; longer if ICU or persistent risk)
monitoring.action: If persistent seizures: escalate ASMs; if refractory: anesthetic infusion; if periodic patterns without clinical correlation: treat underlying etiology
Worsening: repeat cEEG review; assess for ongoing NCSE or new complication

monitoring.frequency: After loading; at steady state (3-5 half-lives); when changing dose
monitoring.action: Adjust dose; check compliance; assess drug interactions
Correct derangements; frequent monitoring if on phenytoin (binds calcium) or valproate
Correct hypoglycemia immediately; insulin for hyperglycemia; avoid glucose variability

monitoring.frequency: If on VPA; if persistent encephalopathy
monitoring.action: If elevated on VPA: reduce dose, add L-carnitine; check for hepatic dysfunction

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q48-72h on VPA/phenytoin; daily on anesthetic infusions
monitoring.action: Drug-induced hepatotoxicity: stop offending agent; hepatology consult
Drug-induced cytopenias: adjust ASMs; consider alternatives
Dose adjustment; hydration; nephrology if worsening
Supplemental O2; intubation if needed; reduce sedating medications if possible
Hyperthermia worsens neuronal injury; antipyretics; cooling; infection workup if fever
Vasopressors if hypotensive (especially on anesthetic infusions); antihypertensives if malignant HTN

disposition.criteria: NCSE resolved on cEEG; consciousness returned to baseline; stable on oral ASMs; identified and treated reversible cause; follow-up arranged with epilepsy/neurology within 1-2 weeks; family educated on seizure recognition
NCSE resolved but continued monitoring needed; transitioning from IV to PO ASMs; etiology workup pending; breakthrough subtle seizures controlled with non-anesthetic agents; able to protect airway
Ongoing NCSE requiring anesthetic infusion; refractory NCSE; respiratory failure; hemodynamic instability; need for continuous EEG with frequent adjustments; GCS <8; intubated patient
Continuous EEG monitoring not available (CRITICAL for NCSE management); epilepsy specialist not available; ICU care not available; neurosurgical evaluation needed
Epilepsy/neurology within 1-2 weeks; follow-up EEG in 4-6 weeks; driving restrictions per state law; etiology-specific follow-up (oncology, rheumatology, etc.)
Recurrent confusion or behavioral change; witnessed seizure; medication non-adherence with breakthrough events; new neurologic symptoms
